Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Persistence of soil organic matter in dynamic landscapes: interactive effects of fire and erosion
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fire, erosion, and soil carbon (C) storage and persistence overlap in space and time. There is incomplete understanding on how and why the interaction of fire and erosional distribution of soil materials control persistence of bulk soil organic matter (SOM) and pyrogenic C (PyC, also referred to as black carbon) in dynamic landscapes. This work will use molecular- and nano-scale techniques to determine how SOM persistence varies along multiple spatial (plot, hillslope, and watersheds) and temporal scales (seasonal, annual, and decadal). The outcome of this project will be better integration of biogeochemical and geomorphological approaches to derive improved representation of mechanisms that regulate SOM persistence in dynamic landscapes that routinely experience more than one perturbation.

This CAREER project will develop improved understanding on the dynamics of bulk SOM and PyC in fire-adapted upland ecosystems and enable teaching of graduate and undergraduate students, and K-12 teachers. This study will generate transformational results in the way to (a) account for changes in C storage in fire-prone systems, and (b) model response of fire-prone upland ecosystems to changes in climate and/or management practices. Moreover, the investigator will: (1) teach undergraduate students and high school teachers about the critical zone, and develop and publish lesson plans for high-school level earth system science; (2) provide scientific training for a graduate student and a postdoc; and (3) learn advanced techniques that she will apply in her research and teaching.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major objective of this CAREER proposal was to further our understanding of how fire and erosion control the persistence of soil organic matter (SOM) and speciifically pyrogenic carbon (PyC, also referred to us black carbon) in soil. This project was motivated by the disconnect that previously existed in our conceptual frameworks of these two controllers (which often co-occur) is preventing proper assessment of the effect of these two common and important perturbations on SOM dynamics. In this work, we employed a multidimensional approach that considers the interactive effects of fire and erosion. We demonstrated how fire, erosion, and carbon (C) storage and persistence overlap in space and time. Our findings showed that increased erosion follows fires, and we quantified the rates at which fire-altered or PyC gets redistributed vertically within soil profiles and laterally to lower landform positions along hillslopes, changing its C sequestration trajectory. Furthermore, this prject included field work in the Sierra Nevada Mountains of California and Nevada (including sites of wild fire in Nevada - Gondola Fire, Calfiornia - Rim Fire, and Prescribed fire site in southern Sierra Nevada in California at the Kings River Experimental Watershed). In the lab, we conducted a series of experiments, including incubations, leaching experiments, spectroscopic characterization of dissolved and particulate organic matter using Fourier Transformed Infrared Spectrscopy and Nuclear Magnetic Resonance spectroscy), elemental and isotopic analyses, and other physicochemical techniques. This project established the relative rates of PyC vs. bulk C erosion, bioavailability and mean residence times of bulk SOM vs. PyC in fire-affected eroding hillslopes, effect of PyC on mineral-OM association in eroding vs. depositional landform positions, and factors that determine the rate of microbial utilization of PyC in dynamic landscapes.

Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit of this CAREER proposal was primarily in the transformative knowledge that was derived on how and why the interaction of fire and erosional distribution of soil materials control persistence of bulk SOM and PyC in dynamic landscapes. In this project we used molecular- and nano-scale techniques to determine how SOM persistence varies along multiple spatial (plot, hillslope, and watersheds) and temporal scales (seasonal, annual, and decadal). Results of our studies will be critical in future efforts that integrate biogeochemical and geomorphological approaches to derive improved representation of mechanisms that regulate SOM persistence in dynamic landscapes that routinely experience more than one perturbation. Findings of this study have already had far reaching implications for improving our understanding of fate of terrestrial OM after it enters streams and other aquatic systems. Furthermore, results of this project are playing important role in establishing how the interaction of fire and erosion will play out under anticipated climate change scenarios, and the implications of these interactions on biogeochemical cycling of essential elements in a warmer world with intensified hydrologic cycle.

Broader Impacts: The broader impacts of this project included training of postdoctoral scholar, graduate and undergraduate students, and K-12 teachers and students. Specifically, we were able to: (a) inform community members on for changes in C storage in fire-prone systems; (b) teach undergraduate students and high school teachers (at UC Merced and beyond) about the critical zone, and develop and we published lesson plans for high-school level earth system science. Furthermore, we worked to promote scientific literacy and national competitiveness in STEM education, as well as increase the number of students enrolled in the Earth System Science Major at UC Merced.
